data.text:
So I read Neuromancer a little while back and, while I liked it at first, as I continued to read I completely lost interest in and comprehension of the story.

However, on a whim, I just picked up a cheap used copy of Count Zero, and was wondering if it would be worth reading in spite of the fact that I was dissatisfied with Neuromancer?

One Man's Opinion

My personal opinion is that the two followups Count Zero and Mona Lisa Overdrive are weak followups to Neuromancer, a book I liked very much.

It think it's Count Zero that has this regularly tempoed cut from plot to plot like- ABC-ABC -ABC until it becomes like a frigging march. That drove me nuts ; I hate when writers do that. I remember Gibson bragging defensively to criticisms that he was an empty stylist, that he could do plot. Well, telling a story in chapters that are exactly the same in length and pace in a continuous, robotic, unceasing plot rotation, is not a good thing. I mean you could use it as a device, but it didn't seem like that was what was going on there. It's a pretty straight ahead SF story.

Mona Lisa Overdrive has a bit more of a relaxed pace. I recall it being more of a mood piece.

He is a great stylist though, and one smart dude -I'm sure he's an even better writer now and has that all sewn up.

I'm tempted to pick up Pattern Recognition soon. That got pretty good reviews.

So, no; if you didn't like Neuromancer, Count Zero is definitely not going to make everything better.
